title: Causes, consequences and lessons that may be learned from policy and administrative failure in the contemporary United Kingdom
abstractText:
The purposes of this research are twofold: 

  • to explain why British governments in recent decades have so often failed to achieve their declared policy objectives
  • to try to identify any general lessons that can be learned from these failures with a view to improving governmental performance in the future. 

The focus of the research will be on domestic rather than foreign policy and on failures that are almost universally acknowledged to have been failures (such as the Poll Tax, the Child Support Agency and a large number of government-initiated IT projects).  Instances of governmental failure will be compared and contrasted with instances of success. 

The research will draw heavily on readily available documentary materials, including Hansard, the hearings and reports of select committees and the reports of such governmental agencies as the National Audit Office and the Audit Commission;  but the documentary evidence, some of which may be obtained as a result of searches under the Freedom of Information Act, will be supplemented by confidential interviews with serving and former ministers of the Crown, officials and other public servants and men and women in the private sector who have taken part in, or been affected by, failed government initiatives.
